before.title: The Email Trap
pain_points: Anxiety every time the 'New Mail' notification pings
Spending Sunday nights 'catching up' on threads
Missing high-value opportunities due to noise

after.title: The Strategic Inbox
benefits: Inbox zero reached daily by 5:00 PM
Only 10-15 high-leverage emails require your attention

items.label: Enable Gmail/Outlook Delegation
items.details: Grant access without sharing your primary password.
substeps: Gmail: Settings > Accounts > Grant access to your account
Outlook: File > Account Settings > Delegate Access
Superhuman: Enable 'Team' features for shared drafting

items.label: Configure Labeling System
items.details: Create a visual system for your EA to categorize incoming mail.
substeps: Create '@Action Required' label for items you must handle
Create '@Drafts to Review' for EA-prepared responses
Create '@FYI' for items you should read but don't need to answer
Create '@Waiting' for items the EA is tracking for follow-up

callout.content: Never share your master Google/Microsoft password. Always use the built-in delegation features to maintain security and audit trails.

items.label: Category: Archive/Delete
items.value: Newsletters, cold sales pitches, and automated notifications that don't require action.

items.label: Category: EA Handle
items.value: Scheduling requests, receipts, simple info requests, and vendor coordination.

items.label: Category: EA Draft
items.value: Introduction requests, project updates, and routine internal communications.

items.label: Category: Escalate
items.value: Urgent board matters, high-value sales opportunities, and personal/confidential threads.

callout.content: Start by having your EA only 'Label' for one week. Once they achieve 95% accuracy, move to 'Drafting' and 'Handling'.

content.text:
To move from triage to full delegation, your EA needs a library of your 'Standard Responses.' This allows them to draft emails that sound like you. 

**The 'Reply with a Number' Paradigm:** 
Your EA sends you a Slack message with 3 drafted options for a request. You simply reply '2' and they send it. 

**Common Templates to Create:**
* **The Soft No:** 'Thanks for reaching out, but I'm at capacity for new projects right now.'
* **The Hand-off:** 'I'm looping in [Name] who is better suited to help with this.'
* **The Scheduling Link:** 'I'd love to chat. My EA [Name] can help find a time, or you can grab a slot here [Link].'

callout.content: Template: 'I'm currently in a deep work sprint and not taking meetings, but please send over a 2-paragraph brief and I'll review it Friday.'

items.label: The 'Missed' Audit
items.details: Review the 'Archive' and 'FYI' folders once a week to see if anything important was miscategorized.

items.label: Voice Coaching
items.details: Provide feedback on drafts. Say: 'This is too formal, I usually sign off with just my initial' or 'I want to be firmer on this specific topic.'

items.label: VIP List Update
items.details: Add new investors, key hires, or partners to the 'Immediate Escalation' list.

faq.question: What if my EA sees a confidential or personal email?
faq.answer: Use a 'Private' label or a separate personal email address for highly sensitive items. Most delegation tools allow you to hide specific threads or folders from the delegate.

faq.question: How do I handle the transition period?
faq.answer: For the first 14 days, do not let the EA send anything. They should draft, and you should review and hit send. Only once the 'Drafts' require zero editing should you grant 'Send' authority.

faq.question: How does the EA handle my specific writing style?
faq.answer: Give them access to your 'Sent' folder from the last 3 months. Have them analyze your most common phrases, your sign-offs, and your level of emoji/punctuation usage.
